This add-on felt to be overwhelmengly obsessed with the original Half-Life and plugging HL references all over the place, instead of developing the alternate point of view. The structure is also very similar to HL: you come to work, ZOMFG! accident, aliens, then soldiers, then you're on the alien world, you come back, and mess about with teleports while obviously being had by scientists.

I think this add-on completely missed out on developing the alternate view point. It did absolute *nothing* to show you the HL events from a point of view of a security guard. You were just like Freeman, trying to GTFO from Black Mesa!

Surely an armed security guard at a secret advanced research facility has some sort of protocol for such events that happened? Even the titles that flash at the start say equipment is first priority, personell is secondary, and personal life is of low priority, yet the only thing you're meant to care in the game is your own life.

A great way to spin this add-on would've been to follow just that recipe: first you try to save some equipment but then realize it's a hopeless and stupid thing to do; we have to evacuate people! Whoever you're helping however are gunned right and left by soldiers and at the end, you're forced to abandon your job ethics, abandon your morals, and fight for your own life.

After the first 5 minutes of the game, the only thing different from this and original HL is that you can't use H.E.V. chargers. Pathetic. I'm only giving a recommendation for the sake of nostalgy.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is the second expansion pack for Half-Life. You play as Black Mesa security guard Barney Calhoun and it’s a parallel story with Half-Life but short. It’s not that good and I’ll explain why. If you remember from my previous review, Half-Life: Opposing Force featured a decent amount of new content for Half-Life. Now this game is like the opposite were there is no new weapons, NPCs, or weapons but instead just a new 90 to 120 minute campaign just slapped onto the original Half-Life game. However this game does feature the new HD pack, where it basically takes existing models, weapons, and weapon sounds and replaces them with newer, better looking ones. This addon also can be used with the original Half-Life and expansion Opposing Force but that’s really not a big deal for this review. I also noticed that the HD models have washed out looking textures on them for some reason compared to when using them in other Half-Life games. As for the gameplay and everything, it’s really the exact same game but with recycled textures and new maps for the single-player campaign (no multiplayer included). For 2001 this game was just bland by this point especially with titles like Halo hitting the XBOX back in the day. However if you can pick-up this game cheap on steam then get it because it’s certainly not a bad game but nice to play through Half-Life again with a new campaign.

What is Half Life: blue shift
Half life: blue shift is a standalone expansion pack for Half Life. Half life: blue shift was originally meant to be part of the Dreamcast version of Half life just like how Decay is for the PlayStation 2 version but unfortunately before the production of the Dreamcast version began Sega announced that they would be discontinuing the Dreamcast, so Gearbox ported Blue shift over to the PC. Half life: blue shift also was the first expansion to include the HD content which was meant to be for the Dreamcast version originally. What the HD content did was that it replaced things such as the MP5 for a higher quality assault rifle and it replaced some NPC models as well, in my opinion i don't really like the HD models so i have turned them off in the options menu.
The story
In Half life: blue shift you play as a security guard called Barney Calhoun who was later used has a main character in Half Life 2. Before the Black Mesa incident Barneys job was to protect the equipment and personnel within area 3 of Black Mesa but when the incident happens your main goal is to escape the facility.

The pros of Half life: blue shift
- Good story that fills in the gap of the Half life story line
- The game has some very good level design
- The AI was very good for its time and still is since they react to different thing such as if you wait near a door the marines will throw in grenades
- You have to interact with NPC's in order to progress through game, this is good because your not just opening doors like you did in the original Half life
- There are decent puzzles and they evenly spaced out in the game
- The game is very enjoyable including the combat even though enemy's can seem like they can take several rounds in the head

What is bad about Half life: blue shift
- One of the most obvious things is that nothing new was really added to the game such as weapons, enemy's etcetera
- The game is very short only taking me around 3 hours to complete and that was without doing the tutorial section of  the game
- I found that the game was easy even though i was playing on hard
- some times i got stuck on the environment such as in between boxes or on the walls located in Xen

Overall Half life: Blue shift is a very good game but does have a few issues but they don't affect the game too much since the game is very enjoyable, also even though the game is very short it is also very cheap so you do get what you pay for. I do recommend getting this game if you like any Half life game or just generally like old school first person shooters like doom, but if that is the case then you would of most likely would of played a Half life game.

[b]Pros[/b]
+Still looks and feels like a Half-Life game/story.
+You finally find out which random security guard is Barney Calhoun. And it would seem that it was none of the Half-Life guards!
+Overloaded with Easter eggs, especially near the beginning.
+HEV chargers are still operational despite the fact that you can't use them. I just found that amusing.

[b]Cons[/b]
-Has some really outlandish puzzles, even more-so than certain Valve puzzles could be. [spoiler]How was I supposed to know that pushing a barrel over two broken wires equals MAKING THE DYNAMITE EXPLODE?[/spoiler]
-Easily the shortest entry in the Half-Life series, even shorter than Half-Life 2: Episode 1 (and I play games at a snail's pace).
-Not much new content in general when compared to Opposing Force. No new weapons, enemies, etc. I mean, there's a new character, so I guess that's something...
-[spoiler]The closest you get to a final boss is making sure the teleporter doesn't explode or whatever.[/spoiler]
-There's a REALLY annoying bug where, if you die and respawn by clicking one of the mouse buttons, your weapon will constantly fire off until you click the mouse button again. I'm not sure if there's a fix for this or even if it's just me, but just be wary of that.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Out of all of the entries in the Half-Life franchise, this is probably the least impactful. In fact, I'm willing to bet there have been mods for Half-Life that both continue the story in its own way and left more of an impact to the player. That being said though, this expansion isn't bad by any means. Just not quite as good as other games in the series.

If you want this game, I'd recommend buying one of the Half-Life complete packs if you don't have a large number of the other entries. You'll get the other entries and save money overall in the process.

Half Life Blue Shift is an expansion pack that takes place during the events of the first Half Life. This time around we play as a security guard called Barney Calhoun. He is mute and plays exactly the same as our last protagonist Gordon. If it wasn't for people calling you by your name you would have no clue you are supposed to be a completely different character.  The same goes for the levels, enemies and weapons. There is zero new enemies or weapons, in fact there are less weapons in this game. Levels themselves are very much like base Half Life, nothing special but definitely of the quality same quality and takes a bigger focus on action. A slight nick-pick I have is that the melee weapon is still a crowbar like the engineer Gordon  instead of a baton that would be far more suited toward a security officer. 

The first thing you will notice starting up the game is that the user interface is now blue instead of orange like the main game. It is probably done to remind you that you are a security officer but has no other effects. The main change is that you no longer refill your “armor” via the wall mounted H.E.V system since you do not have that suit. Instead you scavenge around for usable security armor sets to refill your armor count. One big difference is that unlike the main game this now has a few unique npcs with their own personalities and motives instead of the original's endless army of generic clone npcs. You will also catch a few glimpses of Gordon Freeman from time to time but will never interact with him.

Blue Shift is an expansion pack that plays it very close to home. It has very few changes from the base game and adds nothing new other than a few characters. This is a pretty safe dlc to skip as nothing very important happens story wise. It is more of a four hour adventure for those seeking more of that Half Life experience. In that regard it is a pretty solid dlc if you do not mind the lack of anything new to see. So if you fit that description you will find your fix here but for everyone else this is a by the books dlc that can easily be passed on if you had your fill of Half Life with the base game.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is the last standalone expansion for Half-Life and the last game to take place at Black Mesa. (Decay doesn't count and Black Mesa is a remake of the original Half-Life) You play as Barney Calhoun, a security guard who is trying to survive the events of Black Mesa (See Half-Life & HL: Opposing Force). Personally, I find this game the weakest of all the Half-Life games.
Pros:
-Great to introduce Barney Calhoun as you'll meet him later in Half-Life 2
-Same pros as Half-Life (Great gameplay, great level detail, etc.)

Cons:
-Same weapons used by the great Gordon Freeman (Crowbar and everything) no new weapons like Opposing Force
-Relatively boring story
-Rarely any new enemies unlike Opposing Force
-No Half-Life 3

Overall, this game is OK its not the best Half-Life game. (7.5/10) I recommend this game if your a BIG Half-Life fan, or you want to learn more about Barney before the events of Half-Life 2. However, there is really nothing else to it. I felt that Gearbox could've done a better job with this expansion (See my review of Opposing Force to see what Gearbox can really do).

Данная игра является одним из трёх аддонов для [i]Half-Life[/i], и, как мне кажется, её можно назвать лучшей из этой тройки. Да, игра за военного звучит круче, а игра вдвоём — веселее, но всё же [i]Blue Shift[/i] лучше всех постарался в плане сюжета и сбалансированного геймплея. Сейчас узнаете почему.

Во-первых, данная игра не так длинна, как [i]Opposing Force[/i]. Тут не начнёшь скучать спустя час игры, потому что всё самое важное выражено в всего лишь нескольких локациях по сравнению с бескрайними и некончающимися просторами в [i]Opposing Force[/i]. Во-вторых, сюжет выглядит куда интереснее, чем в других аддонах. Одно дело — когда играешь за героя, который пытается исправить ситуацию, а другое — когда играешь за героя, который не хочет в этом участвовать и ищет пути побега. Трудно поверить, что Барни был именно таким героем до событий [i]Half-Life 2[/i].

Из минусов можно назвать набор HD-улучшений, который улучшает модели, но не трогает текстуры пространства, что придаёт очень странный вид игре. Представьте себе искусно сделанную скульптуру на фоне смазанных красок. Именно так выглядит игра, если использовать этот HD-набор.

If you already played half-life or just didn't have enough money to get it at the time because you spent it all, this is a good alternative. Here, you play as Barney Calhoun, security guard from the Black Mesa incident, as you may of already figured by now. There isn't really any notable change in gameplay that I think I should mention, but one. Since you are a security guard, not a scientest "Grunt"(Refers to the new scientest that they make to all the dirty work so that the others don't have to, A.K.A Gordan Freeman and his HEV suit), you will find that you can not use any of the HEV suit chargers found in the game. Instead, you have to find body armor, vests and helmets, often found by dead security guards lying around the facility. The armor works the same as the HEV suit, however. But, the game is only 3 hours long, as this is just an expansion to the original half-life.
Good mod, nothing super but nothing bad. A small mod that you get to play as the security guard during the events of Half Life 1, an interesting perspective.

I made the mistake of buying this for $5 after i had played through HL1, thinking it would extend the gameplay a little. This expansion, however is terrible as a standalone title. The level design is just not as interesting as it was in the original and ultimately the whole package feels lazy. I found myself feeling more frustrated than elated as i slogged through tests of attrition through gauntlets of soldiers, only to be mortified by more terrible xen jumping sequences from the first game. They were horrible in the first game and they were horrible here. All in all it just felt like a needy sibling, hanging off the coattails of the original's success. Stick with Opposing Force.

I'm on the fence about recommending this one. It's really short, and compared to Opposing Force, which is pretty fantastic, Blue Shift really feels like a 3rd party mod (although I guess [url=www.gearboxsoftware.com]it was,[/url]heh). Something about the level design combined with the stock assets just makes a lot of the experience feel kind of meh. That's not to say it's all like that; it has a better ending than Opposing Force, and I would say the last part of the game as a whole is quite engaging. I enjoyed a lot of my time with this game, I think, but I was bored a lot of the time too. I think it's definitely something to get as part of a deal, rather than on it's own, so yeah.
